Adding a column to track copays and deductibles is a great idea. Here's the updated template:

**Worksheet 2: Expenses**

| Date | Provider | Service/Procedure | Charge | Insurance Payment | Balance Due | Paid | Copay/Deductible | Total Out-of-Pocket |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 2/27/2023 | Primary Care Physician | Office Visit | $ [Insert charge] | $ [Insert insurance payment] | $ [Insert balance due] | [Insert payment status] | $ [Insert copay/deductible] | $ [Insert total out-of-pocket] |

Here's how to use the new columns:

* **Copay/Deductible**: Enter the copay or deductible amount you paid for each appointment or procedure. This will help you track your out-of-pocket costs.
* **Total Out-of-Pocket**: Calculate the total out-of-pocket cost by adding the Copay/Deductible to the Balance Due (if applicable). This will give you a clear picture of how much you've paid for each appointment or procedure.

Example:

**Worksheet 2: Expenses**

| Date | Provider | Service/Procedure | Charge | Insurance Payment | Balance Due | Paid | Copay/Deductible | Total Out-of-Pocket |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 2/27/2023 | Primary Care Physician | Office Visit | $100 | $80 | $20 | Paid | $20 (copay) | $40 ($20 copay + $20 balance due) |

Tips to keep in mind:

* Make sure to update the Copay/Deductible column for each appointment or procedure, as these amounts may vary.
* If you have a high-deductible plan, you may need to track your deductible payments separately to ensure you're meeting your annual deductible.
* Consider using formulas to automatically calculate the Total Out-of-Pocket column, so you don't have to do the math manually.

By tracking your copays and deductibles, you'll have a better understanding of your out-of-pocket costs and can plan accordingly for future medical expenses.
